top_comment.text:
I went to high school in Matsuyama for a little while and on the very first 
day when I was sitting in my classroom, fifty or sixty kids from the other 
classes came up to the hall windows and just sat there for a good ten or 
fifteen minutes tittering and pointing and gasping whenever I looked at 
them. They were practically trampling each other to get a look at me, I 
felt like an exotic zoo animal. I was also followed home by men in their 
cars who would shout stuff at me. Everywhere I went people would giggle and 
gasp and approach me to try speaking English, and I had people ask me to 
sing songs from the movie Frozen because I apparently look just like Elsa. 
Oh well, I guess the tall foreigner with big blue eyes, dirty blonde hair 
and freckles will stick out like a sore thumb wherever I go in Asia.﻿

Omg! This comment made me laughed so hard! But at the same time it made me 
feel absolutely guilty. I used to be like those japanese people except I'm 
not Japanese. I was born and raised in the Philippines, in a small town 
where everyone and I mean everyone is purely filipino. On top of that, it's 
a really really small town or a village whatever you call it, where 
everybody knows everybody, so anyone who's foreign can literally be noticed 
from miles away. Lol! Anyway, I'm gonna try to explain why they act the way 
they do based from my experience when I used to be like them. I hope you 
won't get offended because I tell this to any of my white friends who's 
planning to go to Asia to give them a heads up on what to expect and maybe 
somehow understand the people's side. So back then, I used to think white 
people aren't really people who feels and knows what "filipinos" feel. Like 
I view them as not human beings but more like those actors that I see on 
TV. Because physically you guys are different, so in my head before I 
thought, they're so different, they aren't capable of feeling emotions that 
I feel. I know it sounds ridiculous and even I think it's ridiculous now 
and I'm always so embarass to say this to anyone lol! So yeah, since they 
don't view you as one of their kind, they think it's okay to do things on 
you without your permission because in their minds, you won't be offended 
or you won't noticed, simple because they don't you can. Trust me, I 
learned a lot about the white culture when I moved here in Canada. And the 
first thing I realized was that, we're all humans regarding the racial 
difference and everyone feels the same. This is the time where it really 
got to me and I felt extremely bad for the white people I harrassed back 
then?? LOL! Sorry if this is too long. Hope I shed some light on you. :)

comments.text:
+Mark Fuzuzu England and Wales don't hate each other, not at all. I think I 
understand your misunderstanding of "Miserable negative British attitude", 
you actually are taking our dialect at face value, and missing a lot of 
hidden language, therefore making it seem like British media is all 
depressing. Comparing US to UK television, you will get the impression that 
American TV is happier, when actually the spectrum of emotions displayed 
are biased towards the positive, (Perhaps culturally, as Americans in 
general don't like to show any flaws or have any errors, a lot they act 
like nothing is wrong) in UK media, the range of emotions are mid-tone 
biased, and then depending on the plot, the actor will display negative or 
positive ranges. 

However, it could be as simple as: America has a lot more sunshine than 
England - most scenes shot in England will have a grey overtone, because 
the producers can't stop the English skies being overcast, and so they 
naturally feel more depressing. A lot of American TV and films are produced 
in Hollywood/Calif areas, and so have much warmer, and saturated tones. 
That has a lot of impact on the tone of a media. 

But if you're saying "England and Wales kind of hate each other" then that 
completely explains why you don't understand British media - you simply 
don't understand the English language - as in, the language of English 
people. And if you don't understand that, then you won't understand any 
interaction an Englishman has with you.

comments.text:
I think part of the problem is that people don't actually *look* at you, 
they just scan you superficially, notice one feature (like being short, 
tall, Black or whatver that is and stands out) and miss the rest. This is 
why a busty 5'11 like me is mistaken for a guy (I have a high pitched 
voice, a kinda hourglass built, and generally look fairly feminine, except 
the height - but people do sometimes call me sir anyway - even when I'm 
wearing a flowery dress). The same way, a short girl may be mistaken for a 
12 year old - because people only notice the height, stop there and make a 
retarded assumption. I think it's kinda their problem, not yours. (Still 
hurts, I know).

comments.text:
+Zeno Omairi Honestly, Zeno, being really short is difficult but it's 
something you have to accept and be okay with eventually.
With the everyday problems you may face because of size, there is a unique 
solution... and with every person who treats you with prejudice, there is 
(or will be) another who treats you with respect.
Once I graduated from high school, the number of people who made fun of me 
was reduced *significantly* because I wasn't forced to be around those 
people anymore. There will always be rude strangers, but having friends 
and/or family who don't care how tall you are makes life at least a little 
bit easier.

top_comment.text:
I have a large black beard, and have brown skin. This one time, in downtown 
Seattle, a guy followed me around asking if I was Jewish and asking for 
money. He clearly did not like me. A week later, I see him across the 
street and he tries to attack me in broad daylight, until I said "I'm not 
Jewish" then he walked away.
A month later, he attacks me in a very busy area, with tons of people, and 
shouts that he's going to kill. Nobody does anything. I managed to get away 
from him and call the police, but I had to chase him 1 mile to be sure the 
police got him. He was released in a couple days from mental health court, 
despite a history of violence and theft. It turns out he was a Somalian 
refugee, which is where his antisemitism came from.
So, that's my extreme story about being singled out for my appearance.﻿

comments.text:
+jase276
 Closest to the hiding away thing that I've experienced was one time when I 
was about eleven, I went with a friend to visit her family for Easter. The 
night started fine, with me playing with the new puppies that they had. The 
rest of the family would either be coming over the next day or I would be 
going with them to the other home to meet that family.

Well...plans were cancelled as they stopped to realize that the extended 
family...didn't take too kindly to us of the African-American persuasion, 
lol (I was living in Louisiana...one of the southernmost states in the 
U.S.). So, after already having spent quite some time on the road just to 
get there, I politely accepted the puppy that they had reserved for me and 
while my friend stayed behind to visit her family, the girl's mother took 
me back home. At that age, I was more concerned with ensuring the puppy in 
the back of the truck didn't accidentally climb over the side (I would 
later find her tucked into a spare wheel on the back of the truck, 
completely safe and quite adorable :)

In hindsight though...it's kinda hurtful. I wasn't even given a chance to 
break any stereotypes that their extended family might've had about blacks 
:/ I wasn't even treated like a "unicorn"...more like a pariah.
comments.author: Fluffymiyster

I've never been to Japan....but when I visited a tiny village in Guatemala 
we were the first "Caucasian" people some of those children & even adults 
had even seen...so yeah.....UNICORN EFFECT!!!
We got lots of yummy food & even the nice ladies of the village made actual 
"spaghetti with a rooster tomato sauce" that was impressive just to make us 
feel at home (it was the dish they thought "Americans eat a lot besides 
pizza---which they had no way to make).....so , it was weird but nice.
  
Same thing happened again while living in Mexico for 3 months on a 
humanitarian trip in college....some of the small villages in the center of 
the country (in major drought regions so not a tourist spot by any means) 
in the state of Chihuahua (yes the dog breed of the same name is from 
there) many people had never left their village & never seen any race but 
indigenous Mexican...so the Caucasians, African American & other 
nationalities were awe inspiring & we were very "UNICORN" to them.....in 
fact, I got a ton of attention--to the point of getting to learn to drive a 
manual transmission & ride a horse bare-baked--all because of that group, I 
was the only "American" that spoke accent appropriate/bilingual in 
Spanish....pays to know the language even if they think you are strange!

get married to a man I met in the Navy). I had this happen all the time. I 
figured it was because I was blonde and built like an amazon. But the 
cutest time this happened to me I was in a store deep in the country. A 
little boy holding his brother's hand and carrying some shopping bags 
spotted me and as his jaw dropped he dropped his bags and brother's hand. 
Then leaving his brother behind he followed me through the store for about 
3 minutes. I figured as young as he was and so far from the city he had 
never seen a blonde before. He was very cute though and it made me laugh.﻿

comments.text:
As someone who still talks to squirrels, I feel that the ability to stare 
at actual unicorns (should we ever see them) is something we should all 
cherish. It shows we haven't lost our sense of wonder and can still 
appreciate the less ordinary aspects of the world around us.

Metaphorical unicorns, however, are a different matter. Humans are, 
primarily, pack animals. They don't like to feel alone in the world or like 
they don't belong.
Feel free to appreciate their differences too but do try and do so without 
making a point of it. People who are different are still people and should 
never be made to feel otherwise.

top_comment.text:
I lived in central China for 3 years. Most of the time I lived in a big 
city, which was fine. I travelled to visit friend's family in incredibly 
rural areas, and that was fine. However, when I'd go to a place that was 
neither developed city nor a village, so a sort of big town area, people 
would stare at me. Loads of people had the habit of saying "laowai" (like 
"gaijin") even when I had demonstrated that I understood, and could speak, 
Chinese. One time I had just disembarked from a bus and there was only one 
man on the street. He passed me and said, "laowai". It was a swelteringly 
hot evening, I had just finished a long day at work with no 
air-conditioning, I had taken the wrong bus and was facing a 30-minute walk 
home on a dusty road with no shade... so I snapped. I shouted at him in 
Chinese: "Yes! I know! I know I am a foreigner! Who are you talking to?!". 
His reaction? *sound of surprise* "Ah, she speaks Chinese?" ... =_= I just 
made an exasperated sound, threw up my hands and then stomped away :P 
Soooo, yeah. My personal unicorn moment.﻿
top_comment.author: Danielle Malone

comments.author: Sage Ninja

comments.text:
+Pan Zheng Thanks for the comment, and the clarification. I understand the 
meaning of laowai. I know it does not carry the equivalent meaning of 
gaijin. However, because of a guy called "Da Shan" (a Canadian t.v. 
personality who was really popular in China a few years ago) a lot of 
people on the street said "laowai" in a sing song, high pitched way. 
Apparently it's a reference to a skit where Da Shan said lao wai in the way 
that mimics how Chinese people think English sounds. A lot of my Chinese 
friends would get annoyed when people (almost always guys) would shout it 
at me like that in the street, so I know that it is mocking. That's how the 
guy in my first comment sounded. The majority of the time I ignored it, but 
like I said, I'd had a rough day. I can of course differentiate that 
situation from when someone says laowai to make an observation or to get my 
attention. In those circumstances I would say hello, or introduce myself 
and then chat for as long as time or my vocabulary allow. Many people I met 
on a regular basis came to call me Danni 丹妮, jie jie/mei mei (older/younger 
sister), or wai guo pengyou (foreign friend). One man even called me 
"comrade" haha! I've forgotten the Chinese word for it though.
comments.author: Danielle Malone

comments.text:
just want to clarify. "laowai" is a NEUTRAL word indeed, ( "lao" even shows 
a bit meaning of respect, e.g. you call teacher "lao shi" and friends who 
are older than you: lao + his/her surname). it has no meaning of 
discrimination or suchlike. In contrary, "gaijin", it is kind of rude when 
japs call you that. you should not be sensitive to the word of "laowai". 
some guy in small town, they just feel curious to see a foreigner. and they 
call you laowai and want to see your reaction. they are just too bored...
comments.author: Pan Zheng

thousand comments a day. I don't want you to feel pressured to answer

comments.author: MinaSchokolade

comments.text:
+MinaSchokolade I feel the way you're talking about in America. I don't 
ever wear dresses or skirts in America anymore because I feel really 
uncomfortable by the stares there, and I'll get cat-called and whistled at. 
Here in Japan people are usually much politer about it, as in they stare, 
yes, but no one has ever made me feel uncomfortable here or cat-called me 
yet. They actually make you feel good about yourself because they say such 
nice things, like "She's pretty!" or "She's so skinny!" or things like 
that. And it's not just men, but the women, too. So I actually feel 
encouraged to dress nicely here, whereas in America I feel kind of shamed 
or uncomfortable. :/ I think it really depends on the person, though, 
because I have friends here who have had bad experiences with guys being 
creepy toward them, or even touching them. But I just haven't had any 
uncomfortable experiences here yet so I FEEL safe and confident. 

Even then, though, yeah sometimes I just don't want to be stared at. On 
those days I'll try not to go out, or I'll tone down what I'm wearing or 
even put on a hat or something. Like you, I always feel more comfortable 
when I'm with Jun. But part of that is also because I put a lot of pressure 
on myself to act "correctly" so that I don't give Japanese people a bad 
image of foreigners, so when I'm by myself I'm always freaking out that I'm 
going to do something wrong and make people think, "Ugh, foreigners are so 
rude" or something. >_<
comments.author: Rachel & Jun

top_comment.text:
I did a school exchange in high school to Tokyo, and sure we got a few 
stares in the city but nothing major. When we got to the school though even 
I was midly uncomfortable, and I always have to deal with my friends 
sticking out for being loud and huge anime/marvel comic nerds everywhere. I 
love anime, but I know the boundary between cartoon and reality. In anime 
you always see the students gathering in large groups to see whatever 
commotion has happened or the transfer student blah blah- but I didn`t 
think they actually did that. Me and one other America stopped in the hall 
to visit several old friends, we chat for a bit and took pictures and in 
those ten minutes the entire floor of the school had surrounded us giving 
the unicorn stare. Like all exits were blocked. They dispersed finally when 
the bell rang but then lunch came around, we would just be walking in the 
hall and students would run out of their classrooms, stop in the middle of 
their jog, stop in the middle of their lunch, and stare.
Honestly I felt like the animal in the zoo. They`d whisper amongst 
themselves because none of the other Americans knew much Japanese, but then 
I`d open my mouth and it was like they saw a zebra do a backflip. "Omg shes 
speaking Japanese", my attempt to stop the unicorn effect backfired and 
just gathered more onlookers as they attacked me with questions-getting 
excited every time I spoke. I was very excited when I first showed up and 
everyone was very friendly with me because I understood them, but I was 
quite bothered by the enormous crowds that formed just because we'd stopped 
to talk or get some juice. I love Japan and it`s culture, but maybe next 
time I`ll get a hoodie and sunglasses too. haha﻿

A few days ago, I went to the grocery store to buy some ramen and milk, so 
I grabbed the milk and saw some fruit roll-ups on sale, so I grabbed some. 
Going to the ramen, I realized that I had made a mistake, but it was too 
late to turn back, I was on a mission, now. I put the three boxes of fruit 
roll-ups on top of the two 12-pack boxes of ramen I was getting and lifted 
it with one hand, because I still had the milk in my other hand. I did so 
well actually getting to the register, trying to balance it all, but when I 
put the box down on the belt, the fruit roll-ups decided to nope off of the 
ramen, and all three boxes fell. The lady in front of me gave me the

delicious snacks at people with my mind tentacles.

hermit crab slowly crawling back into my shell.

top_comment.text:
WOW, that was pretty rude of those girls, and not exactly "Japanese" 
courtesy. Sorry Rachel! Okay, here's the one story that I felt was the 
rudest. It even made my mother cry. So I was in Berlin, and only scheduled 
to stay a night (because I had to go to another country the next morning). 
I was hungry, and my mother and I went into a café were they sold coffee, 
and croissants. It was sort of a long queue, but I didn't mind. I went to 
check out some of the bear claw pastries, when everyone in line started 
yelling at us in German!! I didn't understand why they were upset, and 
shouting! They screamed, "You stupid Americans! Damn idiots!" Turns out, 
they thought we were cutting, but we weren't. My mum was so shocked, and 
upset that she ran out of the café, and cried until I comforted her. Why 
did they just assume we were Americans? We did they assume we were stupid? 
I felt like they all needed a chill pill. She now despises ALL of Germany. 
Despite that one silly scenario, I still love Berlin in the winter. :)﻿

I know the "unicorn" feeling. I'm part Dutch, and I used to go to this 
Dutch island every summer. So one day, my mom and I are in a grocery store,

German so I look more German than Dutch)! So, my mom goes to the bathroom 
quickly, and I ask a man where something is. And he doesn't answer me he 
just stares like,
"IT'S A UNICORN!!!"
And so, I raise my voice a bit because I've asked the man the same question 
ABOUT FIVE TIMES NOW. He snaps out of it, and slaps my wrists, and starts 
screaming at me in Dutch! And I'm thinking,
"I'm just a 9 year old girl who wants some groceries!"
My mom comes out of the bathroom, and notices the man and asks me what's 
going on. I tell her what happened, and she starts screaming at the man in 
Dutch. 
Moral of the Story:
Don't ask an elderly man where something is.﻿

+moumann1
Okay, I understand your point! I think the rate of Japanese people is a 
very good reason. When I see someone in Japan, there is a 98.5% chance they 
are Japanese. Those are odds almost anyone would bet on. And they were 
students in rural Japan so chances of them not being Japanese are even 
lower. Even if these two girls specifically weren't Japanese, the point of 
the video was the story so it doesn't make a big difference. People stare 
at me like that all the time in Japan, and many other people have written 
comments here with similar stories in Japan, so I don't think anyone can 
argue this is unusual behavior for Japanese people.

Additionally, I have had other experiences with young girls in Japan where 
they have pointed at me, laughed, and shouted "GAIJIN!!" Jun has told me a 
ton of stories about young Japanese girls who have been rude, and I've been 
in plenty of situations where young girls in Japan have been shrieking in 
public and causing a nuisance, so I don't think this story is out of the 
ordinary.

America isn't a very good comparison because we have a very high mixture of 
cultures and races here. But even with that, I consider everyone I meet in 
America to be American until they tell me otherwise. Even if they don't 
have American citizenship, if you want to be American then typically we 
will consider you American. Anyone can be American, regardless of their 
race, nationality, the language they speak, etc.

Anyway, Japanese people are still extremely polite and overall I've only 
had very positive experiences in Japan. This was just an anecdote.

captions.text:
Hey guys! So people keep asking me things
that I dislike about Japan. And I don't typically

want to be very negative, so I haven't gone
over much yet. I will at some point. But anyway,

so today I'm going to give you a little piece
of that with a story about being a unicorn

in Japan. This is a story about probably the
rudest Japanese people I have ever met in

my life. Okay, so the thing about being a
foreigner in Japan is that Japan is 98.5%

Japanese. An additional 1%, or even more than
that is other Asian people. So you have less

than half a percent of the population in Japan
who is white or black or any other non-Asian

foreigner. If you're in the big cities, of
course this is where a lot of foreigners are

going to gather. And because there are millions
of people there, the chances of you seeing

foreigners are a lot higher. So it's not as
surprising to Japanese people to see white

people walking around in the big cities. But
when you get out into smaller Japan, there

aren't as many foreigners. And that tends
to have the "Unicorn effect." Japanese people

KNOW that it is rude to stare. But when they
see a foreigner, and they're not used to seeing

foreigners, something like clicks in their
mind and they lose all sense of where they

are and who they are, and they just stop and
they will give you an open-mouth stare, like

a unicorn just walked into the supermarket.
Most of the time this doesn't bother me. I

can deal with being stared at. But anyway,
there was this one time that Jun and I were

riding our bikes to the grocery store. And
we were riding along a sidewalk where on the

left of us was a rice paddy, and the drop
off into the rice paddy was very deep. It

was at LEAST a meter deep, at least about
3ft deep. And to the right of us we had a

concrete barrier to prevent us from swerving
out into the road. So what happens when you

have multiple people riding their bicycles
along the sidewalk and they need to pass each

other, is they go single file so that no one
runs into each other and no one falls into

the rice paddy. And this is normal. This is
what happens. So Jun and I see two Japanese

girls coming toward us from a little ways
down the sidewalk. So I ride my bike in front

of Jun so that we go single file, so that
we can pass these girls, like normal people.

These girls—as soon as they come into view
of me, I can see their faces and they are

"Unicorn people." And they stop looking at
where they're going and they open their mouth

and they just stare at me, this entire time
that we're getting closer and closer. And

they don't do anything. It's like they've
completely lost any sense of what they are

doing. They have no idea that they're riding
bicycles. They have no idea there's a rice

paddy there. They have no idea that they're
coming straight toward me and they have not

gone single file yet so there is nowhere for
us to pass. And they keep getting closer and

closer, and I'm looking at them. I'm like,
"Hey, are you guys gonna go single file because

we're gonna run into each other if you don't
do something RIGHT NOW." And no. They don't

go single file, at all. They ride their bike
right into me. Then run into me with their

bicycle, the entire time with their, "IT'S
A UNICORN" face. And they don't say ANYTHING!!

They don't apologize at all! I was so angry.
They just keep riding their bike past me.

The one girl's handlebar like ripped open
my hand and they just freaking drive past

me, turning around, like "WTF UNICORN!!"
That was probably the angriest I have ever

been in Japan. I had like dreams for days
after that happening of like, going back in

time, seeing them coming towards me, and once
they run into me, just picking up their bike

and hulk smashing it into the rice paddy.
Because I was so angry that they couldn't

freaking go single file so that we didn't
run into each other.

So those were probably the rudest Japanese
people I have ever met in my life. And I was

very angry about it. And I'm still a little
angry. So that's kind of an extreme example

of being a unicorn. But it does get kind of
annoying after a while if everyone is ALWAYS

staring at you. There are some times you just
want to go to the grocery store and be like,

"Stop looking at me! Buy your groceries!"
So I do have occasional moments in Japan where

I just don't want to be stared at, so I will
go out with like a hoodie and sunglasses so

I can try to pretend like I'm a Japanese person
who dyed her hair and got a nose job or something.

Anyway, that was my story of being a unicorn
in Japan. I hope you guys will tell me some

of your stories about standing out as foreigners
because I know there are some pretty ridiculous

ones out there. I'll see you guys next time.
Thanks for watching!

title: Being a Unicorn in Japan ユニコーン体験（日本）【日英字幕】
